title: Fermat numbers
content: At first, the (sequence of) Fermat numbers ` FermatNo ` (the ` n `-th Fermat number is denoted as ` ( FermatNo `` n ) ` ) is defined, see ~ df-fmtno , and basic theorems are provided. Afterwards, it is shown that the first five Fermat numbers are prime, the (first) five Fermat primes, see ~ fmtnofz04prm , but that the fifth Fermat number (counting starts at ` 0 `!) is not prime, see ~ fmtno5nprm . The fourth Fermat number (i.e., the fifth Fermat prime) ` ( FermatNo `` 4 ) = ; ; ; ; 6 5 5 3 7 ` is currently the biggest number proven to be prime in set.mm, see ~ 65537prm (previously, it was ` ; ; ; 4 0 0 1 `, see ~ 4001prm ). Another important result of this section is Goldbach's theorem ~ goldbachth , showing that two different Fermut numbers are coprime. By this, it can be proven that there is an infinite number of primes, see ~ prminf2 . Finally, it is shown that every prime of the form ` ( ( 2 ^ k ) + 1 ) ` must be a Fermat number (i.e., a Fermat prime), see ~ 2pwp1prmfmtno .

blocks.name: fmtnorn
blocks.content: A Fermat number is a function value of the enumeration of the Fermat numbers. (Contributed by AV, 3-Aug-2021.)

thm fmtnof1() {
  ⊢ (FermatNo : ℕ0 ↣ ℕ)
} = {
  mpbir2an((FermatNo : ℕ0 ↣ ℕ), (FermatNo : ℕ0 → ℕ), ∀(hs0 ∈ ℕ0, ∀(hs1 ∈ ℕ0,((FermatNo ` hs0)=(FermatNo ` hs1)→ hs0 = hs1))))
  fmpti(hs0, cfmtno, cn0, cn, ((2[^](2[^]hs0))[+]1))
  df-fmtno(hs0)
  peano2nnd((2[^](2[^]hs0)), hs0 ∈ ℕ0)
  nnexpcld(nat2, (2[^]hs0), hs0 ∈ ℕ0)
  a1i(hs0 ∈ ℕ0, 2 ∈ ℕ)
  2nn()
  rgen2(hs0, hs1, cn0, cn0, ((FermatNo ` hs0)=(FermatNo ` hs1)→ hs0 = hs1))
  sylbid((hs0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧ hs1 ∈ ℕ0), (FermatNo ` hs0)=(FermatNo ` hs1), hs0 = hs1, ((2[^](2[^]hs0))[+]1)=((2[^](2[^]hs1))[+]1))
  eqeqan12d((FermatNo ` hs0), (FermatNo ` hs1), ((2[^](2[^]hs0))[+]1), ((2[^](2[^]hs1))[+]1), hs0 ∈ ℕ0, hs1 ∈ ℕ0)
  fmtno(hs0)
  fmtno(hs1)
  sylbid((hs0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧ hs1 ∈ ℕ0), ((2[^](2[^]hs0))[+]1)=((2[^](2[^]hs1))[+]1), hs0 = hs1, (2[^]hs0)=(2[^]hs1))
  bitrd((hs0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧ hs1 ∈ ℕ0), ((2[^](2[^]hs0))[+]1)=((2[^](2[^]hs1))[+]1), (2[^]hs0)=(2[^]hs1), (2[^](2[^]hs0))=(2[^](2[^]hs1)))
  addcan2d((2[^](2[^]hs0)), nat1, (2[^](2[^]hs1)), (hs0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧ hs1 ∈ ℕ0))
  adantr(hs0 ∈ ℕ0, hs1 ∈ ℕ0, (2[^](2[^]hs0))∈ ℂ)
  nn0cnd((2[^](2[^]hs0)), hs0 ∈ ℕ0)
  nn0expcld(nat2, (2[^]hs0), hs0 ∈ ℕ0)
  adantl(hs0 ∈ ℕ0, hs1 ∈ ℕ0, (2[^](2[^]hs1))∈ ℂ)
  nn0cnd((2[^](2[^]hs1)), hs1 ∈ ℕ0)
  nn0expcld(nat2, (2[^]hs1), hs1 ∈ ℕ0)

blocks.name: fmtnorec2
blocks.content: The second recurrence relation for Fermat numbers, see ProofWiki "Product of Sequence of Fermat Numbers plus 2", 29-Jul-2021, ~ https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Product_of_Sequence_of_Fermat_Numbers_plus_2 or Wikipedia "Fermat number", 29-Jul-2021, ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermat_number#Basic_properties . (Contributed by AV, 29-Jul-2021.)

blocks.name: fmtnodvds
blocks.content: Any Fermat number divides a greater Fermat number minus 2. Corrolary of ~ fmtnorec2 , see ProofWiki "Product of Sequence of Fermat Numbers plus 2/Corollary", 31-Jul-2021. (Contributed by AV, 1-Aug-2021.)

blocks.name: goldbachth
blocks.content: Goldbach's theorem: Two different Fermat numbers are coprime. See ProofWiki "Goldbach's theorem", 31-Jul-2021, ~ https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Goldbach%27s_Theorem or Wikipedia "Fermat number", 31-Jul-2021, ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermat_number#Basic_properties . (Contributed by AV, 1-Aug-2021.)
blocks.origin:
thm goldbachth(class c0, class c1) {
  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cn0), wcel(c1, cn0), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), nat1))
} = {
  mpd(w3a(wcel(c0, cn0), wcel(c1, cn0), wne(c0, c1)), wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), nat1), w3o(wbr(c0, clt, c1), wceq(c0, c1), wbr(c1, clt, c0)))
  3adant3(wcel(c0, cn0), wcel(c1, cn0), wne(c0, c1), w3o(wbr(c0, clt, c1), wceq(c0, c1), wbr(c1, clt, c0)))
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cn0), wcel(c1, cn0), w3o(wbr(c0, clt, c1), wceq(c0, c1), wbr(c1, clt, c0)), wcel(c0, cr), wcel(c1, cr))
  nn0re(c0)
  nn0re(c1)
  lttri4(c0, c1)
  3jaod(w3a(wcel(c0, cn0), wcel(c1, cn0), wne(c0, c1)), wbr(c0, clt, c1), wceq(c0, c1), wbr(c1, clt, c0), wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), nat1))
  3adant3(wcel(c0, cn0), wcel(c1, cn0), wne(c0, c1), wi(wbr(c0, clt, c1), wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), nat1)))
  impcom(wcel(c0, cn0), wcel(c1, cn0), wi(wbr(c0, clt, c1), wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), nat1)))
  3exp(wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c0, cn0), wbr(c0, clt, c1), wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), nat1))

  3adant3(wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c0, cn0), wbr(c0, clt, c1), wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), co(cfv(cfmtno, c1), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c0))))
  syl2anr(wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c0, cn0), wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), co(cfv(cfmtno, c1), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c0))), wcel(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cz), wcel(cfv(cfmtno, c1), cz))
  nnzd(cfv(cfmtno, c0), wcel(c0, cn0))

  nnzd(cfv(cfmtno, c1), wcel(c1, cn0))
  fmtnonn(c1)
  gcdcom(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cfv(cfmtno, c1))
  goldbachthlem2(c1, c0)
  3ad2ant3(wcel(c0, cn0), wcel(c1, cn0), wne(c0, c1), wi(wceq(c0, c1), wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), nat1)))
  com12(wne(c0, c1), wceq(c0, c1), wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), nat1))
  eqneqall(c0, c1, wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), nat1))
  3adant3(wcel(c0, cn0), wcel(c1, cn0), wne(c0, c1), wi(wbr(c1, clt, c0), wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), nat1)))
  3expia(wcel(c0, cn0), wcel(c1, cn0), wbr(c1, clt, c0), wceq(co(cfv(cfmtno, c0), cgcd, cfv(cfmtno, c1)), nat1))
  goldbachthlem2(c0, c1)

thm goldbachth(class c0, class c1) {
  ⊢ ((c0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧ c1 ∈ ℕ0 ∧ c0 ≠ c1)→((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))= 1)
} = {
  mpd((c0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧ c1 ∈ ℕ0 ∧ c0 ≠ c1), ((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))= 1, (c0[<]c1 ∨ c0 = c1 ∨ c1[<]c0))
  3adant3(c0 ∈ ℕ0, c1 ∈ ℕ0, c0 ≠ c1, (c0[<]c1 ∨ c0 = c1 ∨ c1[<]c0))
  syl2an(c0 ∈ ℕ0, c1 ∈ ℕ0, (c0[<]c1 ∨ c0 = c1 ∨ c1[<]c0), c0 ∈ ℝ, c1 ∈ ℝ)
  nn0re(c0)
  nn0re(c1)
  lttri4(c0, c1)
  3jaod((c0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧ c1 ∈ ℕ0 ∧ c0 ≠ c1), c0[<]c1, c0 = c1, c1[<]c0, ((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))= 1)
  3adant3(c0 ∈ ℕ0, c1 ∈ ℕ0, c0 ≠ c1, (c0[<]c1 →((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))= 1))
  impcom(c0 ∈ ℕ0, c1 ∈ ℕ0, (c0[<]c1 →((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))= 1))
  3exp(c1 ∈ ℕ0, c0 ∈ ℕ0, c0[<]c1, ((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))= 1)
  eqtrd(((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1)), nat1, ((FermatNo ` c1)[gcd](FermatNo ` c0)), (c1 ∈ ℕ0 ∧ c0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧ c0[<]c1))
  3adant3(c1 ∈ ℕ0, c0 ∈ ℕ0, c0[<]c1, ((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))=((FermatNo ` c1)[gcd](FermatNo ` c0)))
  syl2anr(c1 ∈ ℕ0, c0 ∈ ℕ0, ((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))=((FermatNo ` c1)[gcd](FermatNo ` c0)), (FermatNo ` c0)∈ ℤ, (FermatNo ` c1)∈ ℤ)
  nnzd((FermatNo ` c0), c0 ∈ ℕ0)
  fmtnonn(c0)
  nnzd((FermatNo ` c1), c1 ∈ ℕ0)
  fmtnonn(c1)
  gcdcom((FermatNo ` c0), (FermatNo ` c1))
  goldbachthlem2(c1, c0)
  3ad2ant3(c0 ∈ ℕ0, c1 ∈ ℕ0, c0 ≠ c1, (c0 = c1 →((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))= 1))
  com12(c0 ≠ c1, c0 = c1, ((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))= 1)
  eqneqall(c0, c1, ((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))= 1)
  3adant3(c0 ∈ ℕ0, c1 ∈ ℕ0, c0 ≠ c1, (c1[<]c0 →((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))= 1))
  3expia(c0 ∈ ℕ0, c1 ∈ ℕ0, c1[<]c0, ((FermatNo ` c0)[gcd](FermatNo ` c1))= 1)
  goldbachthlem2(c0, c1)
}

  oveq2d(cfv(cfmtno, co(c0, cmin, nat1)), caddc, co(co(nat2, cexp, co(nat2, cexp, co(c0, cmin, nat1))), cmul, cprod(s0, co(nat0, cfz, co(c0, cmin, nat2)), cfv(cfmtno, cv(s0)))), co(co(nat2, cexp, co(nat2, cexp, co(c0, cmin, nat1))), cmul, co(cfv(cfmtno, co(co(c0, cmin, nat2), caddc, nat1)), cmin, nat2)), wcel(c0, cfv(cuz, nat2)))

blocks.name: fmtnoprmfac1lem
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ fmtnoprmfac1 : The order of 2 modulo a prime that divides the n-th Fermat number is 2^(n+1). (Contributed by AV, 25-Jul-2021.) (Proof shortened by AV, 18-Mar-2022.)

blocks.name: fmtnoprmfac1
blocks.content: Divisor of Fermat number (special form of Euler's result, see ~ fmtnofac1 ): Let F_n be a Fermat number. Let p be a prime divisor of F_n. Then p is in the form: k*2^(n+1)+1 where k is a positive integer. (Contributed by AV, 25-Jul-2021.)

blocks.name: fmtnoprmfac2
blocks.content: Divisor of Fermat number (special form of Lucas' result, see ~ fmtnofac2 ): Let F_n be a Fermat number. Let p be a prime divisor of F_n. Then p is in the form: k*2^(n+2)+1 where k is a positive integer. (Contributed by AV, 26-Jul-2021.)

blocks.name: fmtnofac2
blocks.content: Divisor of Fermat number (Euler's Result refined by François Édouard Anatole Lucas), see ~ fmtnofac1 : Let F_n be a Fermat number. Let m be divisor of F_n. Then m is in the form: k*2^(n+2)+1 where k is a nonnegative integer. (Contributed by AV, 30-Jul-2021.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: fmtnofac1
blocks.content: Divisor of Fermat number (Euler's Result), see ProofWiki "Divisor of Fermat Number/Euler's Result", 24-Jul-2021, ~ https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Divisor_of_Fermat_Number/Euler's_Result ): "Let F_n be a Fermat number. Let m be divisor of F_n. Then m is in the form: k*2^(n+1)+1 where k is a positive integer." Here, however, k must be a nonnegative integer, because k must be 0 to represent 1 (which is a divisor of F_n ). Historical Note: In 1747, Leonhard Paul Euler proved that a divisor of a Fermat number F_n is always in the form kx2^(n+1)+1. This was later refined to k*2^(n+2)+1 by François Édouard Anatole Lucas, see ~ fmtnofac2 . (Contributed by AV, 30-Jul-2021.)
blocks.origin:

blocks.name: fmtno4sqrt

  fmtnorn(hs1, c1)

blocks.name: prmdvdsfmtnof
blocks.content: The mapping of a Fermat number to its smallest prime factor is a function. (Contributed by AV, 4-Aug-2021.) (Proof shortened by II, 16-Feb-2023.)

thm prmdvdsfmtnof(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0) {

  a1i(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cn0), wceq(cfv(cfmtno, cv(hs0)), cv(s0))), wor(clt, cr))
  ltso()
  3syl(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cn0), wceq(cfv(cfmtno, cv(hs0)), cv(s0))), wcel(crab(s1, cprime, wbr(cv(s1), cdvds, cv(s0))), cfn), wcel(cv(s0), cfv(cuz, nat2)), wcel(cv(s0), cn))

  rabn0(s1, cprime, wbr(cv(s1), cdvds, cv(s0)))
  a1i(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cn0), wceq(cfv(cfmtno, cv(hs0)), cv(s0))), wss(crab(s1, cprime, wbr(cv(s1), cdvds, cv(s0))), cr))

thm prmdvdsfmtnof(setvar s0, setvar s1, class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 : ran(FermatNo)→ Prime)
  ⊣ c0 =(s0 ∈ ran(FermatNo)↦ inf({ s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 }, ℝ, <))
  ⊣ d(s0, s1)
} = {
  fmpti(s0, c0, ran(FermatNo), cprime, inf({ s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 }, ℝ, <))
  sylbi(s0 ∈ ran(FermatNo), inf({ s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 }, ℝ, <)∈ Prime, ∃(hs0 ∈ ℕ0,(FermatNo ` hs0)= s0))
  fmtnorn(hs0, s0)
  rexlimiva(hs0, cn0, (FermatNo ` hs0)= s0, inf({ s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 }, ℝ, <)∈ Prime)
  syl13anc((hs0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧(FermatNo ` hs0)= s0), inf({ s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 }, ℝ, <)∈ Prime, < ≺ ℝ, { s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 } ∈ Fin, { s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 } ≠ ∅, { s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 } ⊆ ℝ)
  a1i((hs0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧(FermatNo ` hs0)= s0), < ≺ ℝ)
  ltso()
  3syl((hs0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧(FermatNo ` hs0)= s0), { s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 } ∈ Fin, s0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 2), s0 ∈ ℕ)
  eluz2nn(s0)
  prmdvdsfi(s1, s0)
  sylibr((hs0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧(FermatNo ` hs0)= s0), { s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 } ≠ ∅, ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, s1[||]s0))
  syl((hs0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧(FermatNo ` hs0)= s0), ∃(s1 ∈ Prime, s1[||]s0), s0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 2))
  syl((hs0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧(FermatNo ` hs0)= s0), s0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 2), s0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 3))
  mpbid((hs0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧(FermatNo ` hs0)= s0), s0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 3), (FermatNo ` hs0)∈(ℤ≥ ` 3))
  adantr(hs0 ∈ ℕ0, (FermatNo ` hs0)= s0, (FermatNo ` hs0)∈(ℤ≥ ` 3))
  fmtnoge3(hs0)
  adantl(hs0 ∈ ℕ0, (FermatNo ` hs0)= s0, ((FermatNo ` hs0)∈(ℤ≥ ` 3)↔ s0 ∈(ℤ≥ ` 3)))
  eleq1((FermatNo ` hs0), s0, (ℤ≥ ` 3))
  uzuzle23(s0)
  exprmfct(s1, s0)
  rabn0(s1, cprime, s1[||]s0)
  a1i((hs0 ∈ ℕ0 ∧(FermatNo ` hs0)= s0), { s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 } ⊆ ℝ)
  sstri({ s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 }, cr, cprime)
  sstri(cprime, cr, cn)
  prmssnn()
  nnssre()
  sseldi(inf({ s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 }, ℝ, <), cprime, { s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 }, (< ≺ ℝ ∧({ s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 } ∈ Fin ∧ { s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 } ≠ ∅ ∧ { s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 } ⊆ ℝ)))
  ssrab2(s1, cprime, s1[||]s0)

  diff.hs0.c(s0)
  diff.hs0.w(inf({ s1 ∈ Prime | s1[||]s0 }, ℝ, <)∈ Prime)
  diff.cv.s(s1, s0)
  diffss.ex(s1, s0)

blocks.name: prminf2
blocks.content: The set of prime numbers is infinite. The proof of this variant of ~ prminf is based on Goldbach's theorem ~ goldbachth (via ~ prmdvdsfmtnof1 and ~ prmdvdsfmtnof1lem2 ), see Wikipedia "Fermat number", 4-Aug-2021, ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermat_number#Basic_properties . (Contributed by AV, 4-Aug-2021.)

blocks.name: pwdif
blocks.content: The difference of two numbers to the same power is the difference of the two numbers multiplied with a finite sum. Generalization of ~ subsq . See Wikipedia "Fermat number", section "Other theorems about Fermat numbers", ~ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermat_number , 5-Aug-2021. (Contributed by AV, 6-Aug-2021.) (Revised by AV, 19-Aug-2021.)

blocks.name: pwm1geoserALT
blocks.content: The n-th power of a number decreased by 1 expressed by the finite geometric series ` 1 + A ^ 1 + A ^ 2 + ` ... ` + A ^ ( N - 1 ) ` . This alternate proof of ~ pwm1geoser is not based on ~ geoser , but on ~ pwdif and therefore shorter than the original proof. (Contributed by AV, 19-Aug-2021.) (Proof modification is discouraged.) (New usage is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
thm pwm1geoserALT(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, wff w0) {

  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, cc))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c1, cn0))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)

} = {
  3eqtrd(co(co(c0, cexp, c1), cmin, nat1), co(co(c0, cmin, nat1), cmul, csu(s0, co(nat0, cfz, co(c1, cmin, nat1)), co(c0, cexp, cv(s0)))), co(co(c0, cexp, c1), cmin, co(nat1, cexp, c1)), co(co(c0, cmin, nat1), cmul, csu(s0, co(nat0, cfzo, c1), co(co(c0, cexp, cv(s0)), cmul, co(nat1, cexp, co(co(c1, cmin, cv(s0)), cmin, nat1))))), w0)

  1exp(c1)
  syl3anc(w0, wceq(co(co(c0, cexp, c1), cmin, co(nat1, cexp, c1)), co(co(c0, cmin, nat1), cmul, csu(s0, co(nat0, cfzo, c1), co(co(c0, cexp, cv(s0)), cmul, co(nat1, cexp, co(co(c1, cmin, cv(s0)), cmin, nat1)))))), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(nat1, cc))

  syl(w0, wceq(co(nat0, cfzo, c1), co(nat0, cfz, co(c1, cmin, nat1))), wcel(c1, cz))
  fzoval(c1, nat0)
  eqtrd(co(co(c0, cexp, cv(s0)), cmul, co(nat1, cexp, co(co(c1, cmin, cv(s0)), cmin, nat1))), co(c0, cexp, cv(s0)), co(co(c0, cexp, cv(s0)), cmul, nat1), wa(w0, wcel(cv(s0), co(nat0, cfzo, c1))))

blocks.name: 2pwp1prm

  rexlimdva(hs0, cdif(cprime, csn(nat2)), wa(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(co(co(nat2, cexp, c0), caddc, nat1), cprime)), wbr(cv(hs0), cdvds, c0), wrex(s0, cn0, wceq(c0, co(nat2, cexp, cv(s0)))))

blocks.name: 2pwp1prmfmtno
blocks.content: Every prime number of the form ` ( ( 2 ^ k ) + 1 ) ` must be a Fermat number. (Contributed by AV, 7-Aug-2021.)
blocks.origin:
